abstract.p: Shelley Gaspar letter on plan by Leapfrog Group, headed by leading corporate executives, to steer employees to hospitals that make fewest errors; says emphasis should be on encouraging hospitals to report, not cover up, mistakes (S)

block.p: Re ''Ambitious Effort to Cut Mistakes in U.S. Hospitals'' (front page, Dec. 26):
Re ''Ambitious Effort to Cut Mistakes in U.S. Hospitals'' (front page, Dec. 26):

The Leapfrog Group, headed by eight executives of the biggest companies, intends to steer employees to hospitals that make the fewest mistakes. While I agree that this is ultimately a good idea, the emphasis at first should be on encouraging hospitals to report their mistakes.

Unfortunately, hospitals are businesses, and they are struggling now to keep financially afloat. If the Leapfrog Group tries to influence hospitals financially by having their workers go to hospitals that make the fewest mistakes, it will have a detrimental effect. Instead of rewarding hospitals that are open and honest about their mistakes, it will reward the hospitals that are deceitful and do not report their mistakes.
The writer is a registered nurse.
